ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Better ability to read/understand/discuss high level psych texts, particularly in the field of skill acquisition.
human skill learning
Great readings and discussions surrounding different aspects of skill learning. I loved thinking through how we could improve studies that have been done before.
How complex skill learning is, different techniques to accelerate the learning/retention of skills, how research on skills, especially motor skills, is conducted
motor skill learning, how to read scientific articles and formulate potential studies.
I became better equipped at reading difficult psychology papers and analyzing them. I also learned a lot about the different ways that humans learn skills.
A really interesting look into human skill learning both in definition, and practical uses.
Reading scientific papers, understanding how psychology is studied and understood from an academic perspective.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: You cover a lot of ground within the topic and delve relatively deep into some specific themes, mcdougle is also super nice and great at breaking down the presentations or discussion readings if anything is confusing. I would say my only gripe is that the coursework is not very evenly distributed. Aside from the weekly reading responses and the midterm, all of the work is practically at the end of the semester, making it feel a bit lopsided. The work at the end of the semester is a bit of a lot at once, with a group presentation, group paper, and then a take home final. I think scrapping just one of those bits of work at the end and putting something else earlier in the semester would be better and more evenly balanced workwise. I'm also not a huge fan of group projects, thankfully it went alright because I had a great group (and I imagine most students are upper-level psych/cogsci people so I don't any group would be bad per se), but group work is always just more stressful than solo stuff for me and most others because it's a lot to organize and manage.
Great discussion format. Good distribution of grades over the semester.

The subject matter was well organized and presented. The class was organized so that the 1st half= lecture, 2nd half= discussion, which was a good balance. A final presentation, paper AND exam is a little much at the end of the semester.

Strength: interesting papers, time for class discussion/asking questions, tests are focused on learning the material and not just memorizing it 
weaknesses: workload at the end of the semester was pretty high with group presentation, paper, and a long  take-home exam. Maybe the final paper or one of the papers on the exam could have been replaced with a paper before/after the midterm.

I really enjoyed this course but definitely felt the material was harder than any other psychology course I had taken thus far at Yale. It felt like a big jump from more introductory courses, but I think Professor McDougle made up for that in the way he structured the layout of the coursework and assessments.

Strengths: At the beginning of the semester, I felt very engaged with the course and with the studies we had to read in order to respond to the reading responses. The material was generally interesting when it wasn't too focused on the neuroscience aspect. I also thought that the reading responses were helpful ways to integrate the material that we had learned. Weaknesses: To be honest, I think this class was kind of a mess. The grading system was unclear from the beginning, and the feedback we received on assignments didn't really help clarify the grading structure. Asking the professor about the grading system was also unhelpful; he could never give us a straightforward answer. I also don't think that classes were that interesting or useful; lectures were too short to really understand all of the material, and discussions were dominated by a group of two or three students, making it very hard to get participation points. The class was too big for everyone to participate. I appreciated that the exams were take-home, but I often walked away from these feeling like there was something I missed in lectures; we had to synthesize difficult information and make connections to other topics, which would have been fine if lectures weren't so short. I also don't think that everyone was graded to the same standard, especially in our final group presentations.

I really enjoyed the organization of the class. I found it quite helpful to have a lecture at the beginning of each class to put the readings into context, and enjoyed the discussions of the relevant papers.
You will learn lots of critical thinking. It's laid back, but also you learn a lot. It's less stressful than other courses which makes it more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are looking for a psych seminar either as a psych/cogsci student (or just want to take this kind of course) then 100%. I went into this class a bit unsure of how much I'd understand or get out of it because I have zero neuroscience or computational background knowledge, but it was still very accessible and I learned a lot. If you're looking at this evaluation you probably like psych/cogsci stuff so you will probably like this course even if it's not necessarily a branch that you typically study or prefer.
Yes! Great senior seminar.

This is more of an overview of skill learning research, which ends up conflicting with itself and often boils down to the conclusion that multiple parts and processes are needed to learn skills. Do not take if you're looking for a lot of practical knowledge.
Yes, I got a lot of experience reading psych papers, and designing my own experiment
yes

Most definitely! This course boosted my confidence in my knowledge of psychology concepts and public speaking because Prof. McDougle was so gentle and kind to his students. It was one of the first classes at Yale I felt comfortable speaking in. I am quite shy so the class was exciting to me for that reason.
Only if you're interested in skill-learning and neuroscience. Otherwise, stay far away from this course.
Yes! Professor McDougle is great, and I found the course really interesting, despite not having any specific background knowledge in skill learning.
Yes completely yes the course and professor are amazing.
It teaches you a lot about critical thinking. I would recommend it.
